Legal_Issue: Can the deportation of applicants be stayed based on the pending humanitarian and compassionate (H & C) application and the best interests of their children?
Decision_Outcome: Deportation is stayed until judicial review concludes
Legal_Rule: The tripartite test (serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience) applies. Children's interests must be considered fairly in immigration decisions.
Procedural_Issue: Removal officer inadequately addressed concerns regarding family life and children’s best interests
Grounds_for_Claim: Impact of deportation on children, ongoing H & C application
Review_Standard: Tripartite test: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Removal officer failed to adequately consider children's best interests
Key_Evidence_Considered: Pending 16-month-old H & C application, disruption to family life, impact on children’s schooling, separation of Canadian-born child from community
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H & C) considerations in immigration law
Applicant_Challenge: Removal decision negatively impacts children and disregards ongoing H & C application
Court_Result: Stay of deportation granted pending judicial review
Legal_Rule_Source: Canadian immigration law and administrative fairness principles
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of H & C application, family circumstances, children’s ties to Canada
Remedy_Sought: Interim relief in the form of a stay of removal
Authority: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), Federal Court
Claimant_Status: Applicants facing deportation with pending H & C application
Applicable_Process: Humanitarian and Compassionate application process, removal proceedings
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H & C) application pending for 16 months
Governing_Rule: Tripartite test for interim relief in judicial review
